title: 115_hr2493
content: The Act may be cited as the "Conflicts from Political Fundraising Act of 2017". Congress finds that public confidence in the Federal Government relies on officers and employees avoiding conflicts of interest. The risk arises when nominees or appointees have ties to political entities. This concern has increased since the Citizens United v. Federal Election Commission decision in 2010. Spending by corporations subject to Federal laws and regulations has significantly increased, with some political contributions being anonymous. Current financial disclosure requirements do not mandate reporting of funds donated to political entities, leading to potential conflicts of interest. Public disclosure of political spending is crucial to mitigate actual or perceived conflicts of interest. Public disclosure of political spending is essential to address conflicts of interest by reporting activities to the Office of Government Ethics for negotiation in ethics agreements. SEC. 3. DISCLOSURE OF CERTAIN TYPES OF CONTRIBUTIONS. Definitions in the Ethics in Government Act of 1978 are amended to include the term 'covered contribution' as a payment or deposit of money made by or on behalf of a covered individual to a political organization. The term 'covered contribution' in the Ethics in Government Act of 1978 refers to payments made by a covered individual to a political organization as defined in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The term 'covered contribution' in the Ethics in Government Act of 1978 refers to payments made by a covered individual to a political organization as defined in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, or an organization exempt from tax under section 501(a) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The term 'covered contribution' in the Ethics in Government Act of 1978 refers to payments made by a covered individual to a political organization described in specific clauses, with a total amount not less than the contribution limitation set by the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971. A 'covered individual' is someone nominated or appointed to a covered position, which includes certain specified positions.
